ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The client projects drive the course. If the clients are lackluster, the course will suffer greatly. Face time with clients who are facing sustainability challenges is inherently interesting.
The best aspect is the project we worked on.

To enjoy this course, it is important to find a project that you are excited about. The projects take a lot of time but I found it to be a great experience. Lectures and coaching from Maureen complemented the project well.
Interacting with real-world clients and working on solving real issues.
I enjoyed the variety of projects covering various topics of interest to F&ES students. I especially enjoyed the class visits by current consultants.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The instructional classes should be used to teach practical methods/approaches to tackle a variety of related/common sustainability business challenges, instead of bringing in guest speakers to present on green certifications. This course has a lot of potential, and if we could grow the client base each year, we'd have a better understanding of the status of corporate sustainability. Instead, we have revolving door clients, and our collective memory of what it means to tackle environment/business problems is limited in scope, due to lack of exposure.
Defining a scope and goal of the projects that is challenging and keep students interest going. In general both for my project and the other projects in the class I feel no one did any real work.

The course requires written materials to meet a Flesch readability score of 35 or greater and use no passive voice. This requirement is well meaning but leads to perverse incentives while focusing student effort and time on making reports less professional. The admirable goal would be better met by requiring students to work with advisors from the Yale Center for Teaching and Learning's writing program, or by consulting with professional communicators employed by F&ES and CBEY.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: I think it was poorly cobbled together, and guest speakers came in to discuss what they do, but now how they tackle business & environment challenges for clients.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I thought it would fit nicely, because I believe in the power of the private sector to change the course of environmental outcomes, but we don't do a good job in this particular course to teach FES students how to tackle these problems from a corporate perspective. The lectures don't do much, and then we have to apply our existing skills/approaches to solve client problems, which is problematic.
Capstone course, and good practical business experience

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Because I thought I'd get to work with a cool energy company tackling an important question.
Required capstone for MEM

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Unfortunately, I haven't gained any knowledge or skills from the course. I learned a bit from my client, but the learnings are centered around project management, and in class, we didn't even learn methods for how to do this.
Yes

Generally, yes. I appreciated the thought frameworks reviewed in the early part of the semester, and would appreciate more topics on how consultants do their work. This could include analysis tools, client communications, and client recruitment and development. In addition, the course would benefit with one or two sessions on managing human resources in a consulting environment.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Loved my team. Sometimes our schedules made it difficult to meet all 4 of us.
Great feedback opportunities.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Vet the client, look at the history of engagement with this course. Understand that you won't get any project management skills from the course, but you'll be able to practice your existing style of project management.
Be ready to work Frame out the scope of your project within the first 2 weeks of class; continue to refine as you progress.
Choose a challenging project and work on expanding your own scope, in this class you have to make your own work!
